step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with MCP joint swelling, high transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin, indicating iron overload. Hemochromatosis is associated with calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystal deposition, leading to arthropathy in MCP and PIP joints. While urate crystals (gout) can cause joint pain, the lab findings (high ferritin/saturation) and clinical features (MCP involvement) align more with hemochromatosis-related CPPD. Urate crystals are not directly linked to the lab results here.
